description: Borrowed from Latin recursiō (“the act of running back or again, return”), from recurrō (“run back; return”), from re- (“back, again”) + currō (“run”).

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The act of defining an object (usually a function) in terms of that object itself.
examples: n! = n × (n − 1)! (for n > 0) or 1 (for n = 0) defines the factorial function using recursion.

entries.meaning: (programming) The invocation of a procedure from within itself.
examples: This function uses recursion to compute factorials.
